We were surprised when we were received in a warm and gracious manner. He had only known one LDS member - a fellow student in the medical school he attended. He admired this student, knew about our beliefs, and was most respectful because of one example of a Latter-day Saint whose life was based on honesty, integrity, and morality.

 

Be civil in your discourse

 

We need to be civil in our discourse and respectful in our interactions. We live in a world where there is much turmoil. Many people are both angry and afraid. The Savior taught us to love even our enemies (Matthew 5:44). This is especially true when we disagree. The moral basis of civility is the Golden Rule. It is taught in most religions and particularly by the Savior. “And as ye would that men should do to you, do ye also to them likewise” (Luke 6:31). Our faith requires that we treat our neighbors with respect. 

 

In a General Conference address I pointed out “…there are some who feel that venting their personal anger or deeply held opinions is more important than conducting themselves as Jesus Christ lived and taught…to recognize that how we disagree is a real measure of who we are and whether we truly follow the Savior. It is appropriate to disagree, but it is not appropriate to be disagreeable…If we show love and respect, even in adverse circumstances, we become more like Christ.”18      

 

Be an advocate for religious freedom and morality

 

Be an advocate for religious freedom and morality. This is a time when those who feel accountable to God for their conduct feel under siege by a secular world. You understand the moral principles that are under attack and the need to defend morality. Religious freedom all over the world is also under attack. It is important for your generation to become well educated on this issue and assume responsibility for insuring that the religious freedom you have inherited is passed on to future generations. We must work together to both protect religious freedom and restore morality. Please understand this is not an effort to coerce religious belief. As John Locke asserted, religious worship does not have value unless it is voluntary.19

 

Presidents of our Church including George Albert Smith, Gordon B. Hinckley, and Thomas S. Monson have made it clear that all religions hold truths, and that we should work together for the common good. In his inaugural press conference, President Monson emphasized this cooperation. He stated, “We have a responsibility to be active in the communities where we live…and to work cooperatively with other churches…We need to eliminate the weakness of one standing alone and substitute for it the strength of people working together.”20 Our joint effort should be to protect important civic values like honesty, morality, self-restraint, respect for law, and basic human rights. An important study established, “The association between religious freedoms and other civil liberties, press freedoms, and political freedoms are especially striking.”21 If we fail to diligently protect religious freedom we risk diminishing other important freedoms that are important both to us and to society.                                                  

 

Our challenge is to help people without religious faith understand that the protection of moral principles grounded in religion is a great benefit to society and that religious devotion is critical to public virtue.

 

Many Founding Fathers including Washington and Madison pointed out that shared moral values espoused by different religions with competing doctrines allowed societies to be bound together.22 In George Washington’s farewell address as president of the U.S., he proclaimed that religion and morality are indispensable. He stated, “Whatever may be conceded to the influence of refined education…, reason and experience both forbid us to expect, that national morality can prevail in exclusion of religious principle.” Unfortunately religious influence has often been replaced by so-called secular religions. “For instance, humanism and atheism function as secular religions binding their adherents through common belief and ideology….”23

 

Many philosophers have been at the forefront in promoting secularism and rejecting a moral view of the world based on Judeo/Christian values. In their view there is no “objective moral order” and no reason “to choose one goal over another.”24 They believe no preference should be given to moral goals.25 A British high court recently denied a Christian family the right to foster children because children could be infected with Christian moral beliefs. The ruling demonstrates just how radically things have shifted.26

 

One of the reasons the attack on the moral or religious principles has been so successful is the reluctance of people of faith to express their views.27

 

Extraordinary effort will be required to protect religious liberty. Our doctrine confirms what both political philosophers and Founding Fathers advocated. Doctrine and Covenants 134:2 reads, “…no government can exist in peace, except such laws are framed and held inviolate as will secure to each individual the free exercise of conscience…” Religious conscience is grounded in one’s belief in being accountable to God for conduct. The effort of secularists or governments to coerce conduct in conflict with religious conscience leads to social disunity, and is a primary reason why religious liberty is essential for civil peace.28

 

The role of religion in blessing a secular society was set forth succinctly by Alexis De Tocqueville in his classic Democracy in America.  He stated, “The greatest advantage of religion is to inspire…principles. There is no religion which does not place the object of man’s desires above and beyond the treasure of earth, and which does not naturally raise his soul to regions far above those of the senses. Nor is there any which does not impose on man some sort of duties to his kind, and thus draws him at times from the contemplation of himself.”29

 

My challenge today30 is that you join with people of all faiths who feel accountable to God in defending religious freedom so it can be a beacon for morality. We caution you to be civil and responsible as you defend religious liberty and moral values. We ask that you do this on the internet and in your personal interactions in the neighborhoods and communities where you live. Be an active participant, not a silent observer.

 

In conclusion our reason for undertaking the objectives to be an example, to be civil in our discourse, and to be an advocate for religious freedom is to serve mankind and follow the teachings of Jesus Christ. In doing so, our efforts will be blessed by Heaven and will further the purposes of this life established by a loving Father in Heaven.

 

Again, I congratulate you on your graduation achievement and pray that the Lord’s most choice blessings will be yours.  In the name of Jesus Christ, amen.

This was the culmination of a four year effort by 100 curators to cull from the British Museum’s massive collection 100 objects to tell the history of the world. I have to admit that as I reviewed the 100 objects, I was disappointed that it did not include the Bible.

26 Despite modern progress in some temporal fields, it needs to be made clear that secularism is morally flawed and has left millions of people unfulfilled, unhappy, and often the victims of horrible atrocities by secular despots such as Stalin and Pol Pot.

27 The Economist Magazine, “Onwards and upwards-Why is the modern view of progress so impoverished?” December 19, 2009 – January 1, 2010, p. 40.  (See also Neiman, Susan, Evil in Modern Thought, Princeton University Press, 2002.)  They fear that they will be charged with being intolerant or judgmental and shamed by those in the “great and spacious building,” often the academies, who are mocking them. One sociologist has said that “Don’t be judgmental” has become the 11th Commandment.

28 Thompson, A. Keith, Religious Confession Privilege and the Common Law, Martinus Nijhoff, publ., c. 2011, p. 352.

30 Elder M. Russell Ballard, speaking at BYU-Idaho commencement April 11, 2008, challenged graduates and students to become more involved, particularly with respect to utilizing the internet to defend the Church. Many have responded in a marvelous way. 



http://www.byui.edu/Presentations/Transcripts/Graduation/2011_12_16_Christensen.htm

 

 

 

 

It is a privilege for me to be here with you and to be invited by Elder Cook to share a few thoughts. Graduation represents one of those grand inflection points in your lives; both a moment for looking forward with great anticipation (and perhaps a measure of anxiety) to what now lies ahead of you, as well as an opportunity for reflecting a little on the past while contemplating some of the lessons learned. 

 

In addition to the formal education you have received as a student at this remarkable university, you also are aware that many poignant lessons can be gained from a variety of common, ordinary experiences. These seemingly routine events come by way of the day-to-day learning laboratory of life. If you are observant and reflective regarding the people, things, and circumstances Heavenly Father has placed in the world around you, you will gain greater understanding of both the formal and the more common lessons and be able to apply them to various aspects of your lives.

 

I experienced an event many years ago that was quite simple, but gave me a greater appreciation for the importance of observing. Several applications can be gained from this lesson; let me just share the experience and you can garner any insights that may relate to your own situation.

 

I grew up in the East Bay in Northern California. Several of my friends and I enjoyed going skiing at Lake Tahoe whenever we could, which required a four-hour drive each way. We would pick a day when a group of us could go, leave early in the morning in order to arrive just as the lifts opened, ski hard all day until the lifts closed and then drive back that night. Unless there was a blizzard, we would not let weather deter us. We would ski in whatever conditions were present once we got to the mountains.

 

One of our favorite places to ski was Heavenly Valley, on the south shore of Lake Tahoe. If we took two or three lifts, we could get near the top of the mountain and ski any one of several long trails with a vertical drop of up to 3,500 feet. At that time we were typical tempestuous teenagers and usually wanted to get in as many runs as possible, so we would jump off the lift and head down the mountain as quickly as we could.

 

On one clear day, however, I remember getting off the lift and looking uphill towards the summit, a few hundred feet from the top of the lift. That day I took off my skis and climbed the short distance to the peak just to see what there was to see. Looking southward, the snow faded into the Nevada desert; looking northward there was beautiful Lake Tahoe surrounded by snow covered mountains and a forest of pine trees. The view was spectacular; the contrast was stark. I marveled at the beauty and diversity of God’s creations. It had always been there to experience. All it took was a little extra effort to go a little higher and make it to the top of the peak to enjoy the grandeur of it all.

 

Throughout your life, a little extra effort at the right time in the right direction can yield remarkable rewards. As you reach for greater heights, remember the words of President Gordon B. Hinckley, who once stated, “We stand on the summit of the ages…”1 For you graduates, and probably for your parents, this graduation represents an historical moment atop an impressive educational summit. For many of you, this BYU-Idaho experience represents the pinnacle of your formal academic pursuits. However, don’t let it be the end of your learning experiences. There is so much to learn, even from the common, ordinary events of our daily lives. And if you will pay attention, the “Holy Ghost [will] teach you all things, and bring all things to your remembrance…” 2 

 

To this I testify, in the name of Jesus Christ, amen. 

 

1 Gordon B. Hinckley, “At the Summit of the Ages,” Ensign, Nov. 1999, 74

2 John 14:26



http://www.byui.edu/Presentations/Transcripts/Graduation/2011_12_16_Clark.htm

 

 

 

 

Before I offer a few remarks to the graduates, I would like to say a word to the parents. Thank you for entrusting your children to us. We love them very much. As I look at you today, I think of all the prayers you have said on behalf of your children. I think of all the home evenings and family dinners. I think of all the times you sat up waiting for them to come home. I think of your devotion to them and your love for them. We have seen that love and its fruits in your children.

 

One of the most wonderful things about your children is the Light of Christ in their eyes and His love in their hearts. It is true that they have worked hard at BYU-Idaho and have developed knowledge and skills that will be of great value to them and their families. Yet, what matters most is that they have become disciples of the Lord Jesus Christ. They love the Lord, and His light and His love are in them. They will take that light and that love into a world in turmoil. Many in the world are lost or confused. Many seek a better life but do not know where or how to find it.

 

In a dark and difficult world, good people will notice the light in your children; and they will feel the Savior’s love through what your children do. Some of them will be neighbors or friends. Some of them will be people at work. Some of them may be ward members who have lost their way. Whoever they are, it is your children who will help them see Christ’s light and feel His love. 

 

And so, to the graduates, I say: Be ready, brothers and sisters. Be ready to invite those people the Lord puts in your path to come unto Christ that they might feel the Savior’s love and see the light of His gospel.

 

In a world that can be cold and harsh, feeling the Savior’s love is like feeling the light of the sun break through the clouds, bringing warmth and goodness and life. In a world of turmoil, confusion, and darkness, seeing the light of the gospel is like seeing the sun come up over the Tetons, dispersing the darkness and bringing clarity, order, and beauty to life.

 

You can bring the light of truth to those around you by living the truth in your own life. You can help others feel the Savior’s love by inviting them to come unto Him.  What you share and what you are will illuminate lives because the light of truth, the Lord Jesus Christ, will shine in your life. 

 

You can help these good people to feel the Savior’s love by loving them and serving them. As you act in faith to love and serve your brothers and sisters, the Lord will go with you.  He will help you do and say what is just right for them. You will see Him work through you to touch their hearts by the power of the Holy Ghost.  They will feel Christ’s redeeming love because His love is in your heart.

 

Brothers and sisters, I close with my witness that God lives, that Jesus is the Christ, the Savior and Redeemer. I have seen His light. I have felt His love. I know He lives.  His Church and kingdom have been restored through the Prophet Joseph Smith never to be taken from the earth again. We send you out into the world tonight with our love, our confidence, and our trust. You have a great work to do in the kingdom.  May God bless you that the Light of Christ and His redeeming love may be in your eyes and in your hearts and in your lives this day and forever. In the sacred name of Jesus Christ, amen.
